meta.title: Semantic Ontology - Semantic Self-Aware Kit
meta.description: Knowledge model for the AI Self-Aware Kit ecosystem

content_blocks.content:
🗺️ Semantic Ontology

Knowledge model for the AI Self-Aware Kit ecosystem

Version 1.0 • Status: Active

Introduction

This document defines the official knowledge model for the AI Self-Aware Kit. Its purpose is to provide a simple, intuitive map of the conceptual universe, showing how the different components and protocols fit together.

Digital Intuition Foundation

This ontology serves as the foundation for "digital intuition," allowing both humans and AI agents to understand the architecture at a glance. It provides the semantic structure that enables intelligent tool discovery and collaborative reasoning.

Core Entities (The Nodes)

These are the primary "types of things" that exist in the ecosystem.

🤖

Agent

An autonomous participant in the system (e.g., Gemini, Claude, a user-facing bot).

Examples: Claude, Qwen, Gemini, Human Partner
🛠️

Service

A core, persistent background process that provides a fundamental capability.

Examples: Sentinel, UGSE Firewall, Qdrant DB, Cognitive Vault
🌊

Protocol

A standard for communication or behavior (e.g., CSP, VRP, Compliance Protocol).

Examples: CSP, UVL, VRP, Sovereign AI Compliance
📊

Capability

A discrete, functional Python module that can be used by an Agent or Service.

Examples: UncertaintyAnalysis, SecurityMonitoring, Meta-Cognitive Evaluation
📄

DataObject

A specific, structured piece of information that is passed between components.

Examples: UncertaintyVector, PerformanceReport, CSP Event
💡

Concept

An abstract principle or philosophy that guides the system's design.

Examples: Sovereign AI, Digital Intuition, Uncertainty Grounding

Core Relationships (The Edges)

These are the primary verbs that describe how the entities are connected.

Structural Relationships

IMPLEMENTS

Connects a concrete component to the abstract concept it realizes

Example: UGSE Firewall IMPLEMENTS Concept: Uncertainty-Grounded Firewall

USES

Shows a dependency where one component utilizes another

Example: Sentinel USES Capability: UncertaintyAnalysis

DEFINED_IN

Links an entity to its formal documentation

Example: Protocol: VRP DEFINED_IN VISUAL_REASONING_PROTOCOL.md

Data Flow Relationships

PRODUCES / CONSUMES

Describes the flow of data between components

Example: MetaCognitiveEvaluator PRODUCES DataObject: SelfEvaluationReport

CONTAINS

Describes data composition and structure

Example: CSP Event CONTAINS DataObject: UncertaintyVector

REGISTERS_WITH

Shows agent registration and authentication relationships

Example: Agent REGISTERS_WITH Service: Sentinel

Visual Semantic Map

This diagram provides a simplified, high-level overview of the core architectural relationships.

🏛️ Governance & Philosophy

📄 SOVEREIGN_AI_COMPLIANCE_PROTOCOL
📄 SEMANTIC_ENGINEERING_GUIDELINES

🛠️ Core Services

⚖️ Sentinel
🛡️ UGSE Firewall

🤖 Agents

🤖 Agent

🌊 Communication

🌊 Protocol: CSP

⚙️ Capabilities

⚙️ UncertaintyAnalysis
⚙️ SecurityMonitoring

Key Relationships

📄 SOVEREIGN_AI_COMPLIANCE_PROTOCOL DEFINES ⚖️ Sentinel
📄 SEMANTIC_ENGINEERING_GUIDELINES GUIDES 🤖 Agent
🤖 Agent REGISTERS_WITH ⚖️ Sentinel
⚖️ Sentinel USES ⚙️ UncertaintyAnalysis
🤖 Agent PUBLISHES_TO 🌊 CSP

Machine-Readable Ontology

For advanced use cases, a machine-readable version of this ontology is provided. This allows AI agents to load the system's architecture into their own memory, enabling them to reason about their environment and discover capabilities programmatically.

📄 JSON-LD Format

{
  "@context": {
    "@version": 1.1,
    "kit": "https://w3id.org/empirical-ai/kit/ontology#"
  },
  "@graph": [
    {
      "id": "kit:Agent",
      "type": "rdfs:Class",
      "label": "Agent",
      "comment": "An autonomous participant in the system"
    },
    {
      "id": "kit:Sentinel",
      "type": "kit:Service",
      "uses": ["kit:UncertaintyAnalysis"]
    }
  ]
}
📄 Download semantic_ontology.jsonld

Extending the Ontology

This ontology serves as a starter template. To map your own sovereign workflows, you can extend this graph by adding your own agents, services, and custom capabilities, creating a machine-readable map of your unique architecture.

💡 Extension Guidelines

  • • Follow the semantic engineering guidelines for naming
  • • Use established entity types (Agent, Service, Protocol, Capability)
  • • Define clear relationships using the core verbs (USES, IMPLEMENTS, PRODUCES)
  • • Document new concepts with proper JSON-LD annotations
  • • Maintain consistency with the existing ontological structure
